item.title: Mowing Sideways
item.description:
Caprine-aware search giant Google reports from its Mountain View HQ.

This spring we decided to take a low-carbon approach: Instead of using noisy mowers that run on gasoline and pollute the air, we’ve rented some goats from California Grazing to do the job for us (we’re not “kidding”).

Mountain “View”, eh? All looks suspiciously flat in the photo posted on the official google blog, but goats do offer another advantage: great traction on slopes. I took this photo today of two which have kept the 50% slope of the Royate Hill nature reserve (situated on top of a seven span railway viaduct!) trim for far longer than the google flock have been operating.
item.author: tag@wordaligned.org (Thomas Guest)

item.title: Google maps for the human-powered
item.description:
I noticed that, at last, Google Maps has started to offer directions for pedestrians as well as motorists. One important difference for urban journeys is that you can walk in either direction along a one-way street.

The site warns about its beta status.

Another important difference is that pedestrians can cross roads and use footpaths which cars cannot; similar considerations apply to cyclists. However hard I tried I couldn’t get google maps to detect the vital passage for cyclists and walkers into Freemantle Square at the top of Nine Trees Hill, high spot of my commute to work. Look how tangled it gets!

item.title: Google street view is watching you
item.description: At about quarter past 3 today, on my way to collect the kids from school, I was sitting on my bike at the traffic lights on Cheltenham Road, waiting to turn right onto Ashley Road, when a Google surveillance unit swept past — a compact dark car with hi-tech recording equipment mounted on a sturdy pylon rising a couple of metres from its roof and a discreet Google logo on each door.
